gmd:metadataStandardName.gco:CharacterString: ISO 19139 Geographic Information - Metadata - Implementation Specification

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: This dataset contains Historic Landmarks (by structure) officially designated by the District of Columbia. This is a consolidated collection of structures with historical significance within the District of Columbia as listed in the "District of Columbia Inventory of Historic Sights". It contains the locations and attributes of buildings Additional datasets are available of Historic Districts. The same records in this polygon-format dataset are also available in a point-format dataset.

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString: This is a spatial dataset of record for the storage, maintenance, and display of historically significant structures within the District of Columbia for planning and management purposes.

gmd:keyword.gco:CharacterString: Washington, District of Columbia, United States

gmd:useLimitation.gco:CharacterString: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License.
Acknowledgment of the DC Office of the Chief Technology Officer (OCTO), the DC Office of Planning (DCOP) & the DC State Historic Preservation Office (HP).

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: publication date

gmd:supplementalInformation.gco:CharacterString: The original data source for this dataset is the "District of Columbia Inventory of Historic Sites", published in September 2004 by the DC State Historic Preservation Office (HP). Updates at the Office of Planning in December 2006 were based on manual review of hard-copy maps and subsequent on-screen digitizing of updates as provided by David Maloney of the State Historic Preservation Office. This update (2012) re-organizes the schema and updates with new landmarks and incorporates other historic areas.

gmd:measureDescription.gco:CharacterString: Data believed to be complete and accurate, subject to change.
Data believed to be complete and accurate, subject to change. Digital version compared with original source data for accuracy and completeness. Validated by source and/or responsible agency.
Data believed to be complete and accurate, subject to change. Digital version compared with original source data for accuracy and completeness. Validated by source and/or responsible agency.
Data believed to sufficiently accurate for planning purposes. Boundaries may not align perfectly with other DC GIS data sets.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Added new location for Ft. Stanton(Civil War Site). Deleted older, incorrect location (Source R.Trocolli, NPS)
Landmarks that include several adjacent rowhouses require a negative buffer of 0.1 meters to keep geometry of each individual rowhouse separate when records are merged.

Phase I - Historic Inventory Database Version 1 Attribute Analysis Updated Inventory database with values from new Inventory document (July 2002). Identified inconsistencies between spatial dataset attributes and Inventory attributes.

Phase II - Historic Inventory Database Version 2 Between 07/16/2002 and 09/22/2004, the content and structure of the "Inventory of Historic Sites" document was updated, revised, and reformatted. In addition to supplying new content, the structure of the document was changed from an alphabetical ordering to an ordering by historical eras and cultural themes. Most of the original landmark entries still existed, but many underwent name changes or content expansion. The Historic Inventory database underwent a corresponding upgrade. Fields were added to accomodate the Era/Theme hierarchy of the new document. New entries were added and records updated, as appropriate. The Inventory document contains entries for many types of historical entities. It can also have single entries which contain a listing of individual locations. Three types of spatial features were determined to describe entities within the Inventory document, Landmark Areas (Historic Districts, Parks, Cemeteries, etc.), Landmark Structures (Buildings, Memorials, Fountains, etc.), and Landmark Sites (Point Locations). Overlap between spatial features was expected between Landmark Sites and Landmark Areas or Structures. In addition, individual Landmark Sites or Areas might exist. Three GIS ID fields were used to link records in the Inventory Database to their corresponding spatial entity (Landmark Areas, Structures, or Sites). These fields were added to the original Inventory table and to a Collections table that tracked individual locations within single Inventory document entries.

Updated Historic Inventory by adding new records that constituted a 'historic structure' and a new column of 'area types.' Added column for 'historic designation' and 'eligibilty.' Updated 'label' column to make labels more compact.

Phase V - Spatial Data Validation All address points have been validated against the Master Address Repository (MAR) dataset and the current DRAFT Taxlot and Recordlot property boundaries. Only the first 93 entries from the Inventory of Historic Sites document were validated in this phase, plus updating the attribution of the Landmark Areas / Historic Districts dataset. This constitutes the first major section of the document, "The Federal City". Subsequent document chapters will be processed and validated sequentially. After the major issues were addressed, Historic Preservation Staff reviewed the Location and names of all landmark structures and sites within the dataset. Proof maps were generated and changes or updates were noted where appropriate. DC Office of Planning GIS Staff reviewed and prepared the updates.

Phase IV - Spatial Data Validation Several fields were added to maintain consistency with the DCGIS spatial data model ([OBJECTID], [AID], [WEB_URL], and [UPDATE_DATE]). Two additional fields ([LABEL] and [NR_ELIGIBLE]) were incorporated into the updated dataset. [LABEL] is used to indicate a feature's name on a display or map. [NR_ELIGIBLE] is a flags that indicates whether the feature is eligible for entry in the National Register list. DCOP and Historic Preservation staff performed a visual validation of the Landmark Areas dataset. Area boundaries were plotted and checked against DRAFT vectorized lot lines (Tax lot / Record lot), as well as planimetric features, as needed. Numerous new Landmark areas and Historic Districts were added to the dataset.

Phase I - Historic Inventory Database Version 1 Spatial Analysis Analytical review of spatial historic datasets in DC Atlas. These include Historic Landmark Sites, Historic Landmark Areas, and Historic Districts. On the whole, the data sets were found to be coarsely digitized and their attributes were referenced against a document that was several years out of date.

Phase I - Historic Inventory Database Version 1 Attribute Analysis Historic Preservation staff performed research and update against the Inventory database (Version 1) to clarify discrepancies between the current Inventory document and the current spatial datasets.

Phase III - Spatial Data Collection and Creation The "Inventory of Historic Sites" document addresses a wide variety of features. Using the current DCGIS historic spatial features as a guide (Historic Districts, Landmark Areas, Landmark Sites), DCOP staff began assembling related spatial data sources. A simple attribution scheme was defined for the three spatial datasets (GIS_ID, NAME, ADDRESS, SSL). Detailed attribution that mirrored the content of the Inventory document would be managed in the Inventory database and would be linked to the appropriate spatial dataset(s) by a unique GIS ID. The assembled spatial data sources were stripped of attribution and replaced with the simple attribution scheme (GIS_ID, NAME, ADDRESS, SSL). The table below details the relationships between the GIS ID in the Inventory database to the individual spatial datasets. Landmark Inventory Format Spatial GIS Link Type ID Dataset Area LND_ID LND_0000 LandmarkPly GIS_ID Structures HSE_ID HSE_0000 LandmarkBldg GIS_ID Sites SSL_ID SSL_0000 LandmarkPt GIS_ID Assembled all data sources that had undergone attribute reduction and consistency into source Personal Geo-database. Developed ArcMap MXD for updating component data sources including: Landmark Areas HistDisPly Historic Districts (DCOP) Reservations DC Reservations (DCOP) CemeteryPly Cemeteries (DCGIS) LandmrkPly Old Landmark Areas (DCGIS) WaterPly River Boundaries (DCGIS) RoadPly Road Boundaries (DCGIS) ParkPly NPS Parks (NPS) Landmark Structures BldgPly Building Footprints (DCGIS) Landmark Sites OwnerPt Owner Points (DCGIS) PlacesOfWorship Churches (DCGIS) Concurrently walked through the Inventory Document, Inventory Database, and Spatial Data Locator (ArcMap). Determined that each document entry has a spatial data equivalent. Concurrently assign a unique GIS ID to Inventory Database and associated spatial dataset. If no spatial data exists, designate "GIS Placeholder" within Inventory Document text. In the event that a single Inventory Document entry references multiple spatial locations (collections), individual location records were created in a separate table. GIS features were created and/or attributed, as appropriate. Collection records included a link back to the original Record ID as well as simple descriptive information. The location and visual validation of the Landmark Structures and Landmark Sites was facilitated by two tools developed by DC Office of Planning (DCOP) staff. An address geocoder utility allowed GIS staff to zoom into a specific location (address) as defined in the Inventory record. In addition, a Pictometry Viewing utility enebled staff to view a given location (structure) close enough for visual clues. These two tools in conjunction with referencing to Historic American Building Survey (HABS) website found the majority of sites.

Phase I - Historic Inventory Database Version 1 Attribute Analysis Attribute components of the spatial datasets (Historic Landmark Sites, Historic Landmark Areas, and Historic Districts) were imported to an MS Access database. Began process to convert text document ("Inventory of Historic Sites - 2000") from text format into tabular format. Fields were made for block text entries and detailed data was extracted from these. Created fields that corresponded to spatial dataset attributes for future comparative analysis. Loaded spatial dataset values and determined associations between spatial data features and Inventory items. Identified inconsistencies between spatial dataset attributes and Inventory attributes.
Updated location of Ulysses S. Grant School (School without Walls)
Schema updated and new landmarks added from 2006 through 2011.
Updated to incorporate landmarks designated in 2011 and 2012 and additional schema changes
